docs.lead_paragraph: The makers of vitamins, herbs and dietary supplements may market products for natural conditions like morning sickness, hot flashes and memory loss in aging without proving they are safe or effective, the Food and Drug Administration announced today. The decision, which reverses an earlier proposal, marks the latest in a series of legal and regulatory victories for the dietary supplement business, which has been growing by leaps and bounds since Congress passed a law in 1994 that severely restricted the F.D.A.'s authority to regulate the industry.

headline.main: Rule on Ads for Diet Supplements Is Revised

docs.snippet: The makers of vitamins, herbs and dietary supplements may market products for natural conditions like morning sickness, hot flashes and memory loss in aging without proving they are safe or effective, the Food and Drug Administration announced today....

docs.lead_paragraph: So is that ''The Wild Party'' featuring Mandy Patinkin or ''The Wild Party'' featuring Taye Diggs? ''The Wild Party'' written by Andrew Lippa or the one by Michael John LaChiusa and George C. Wolfe? ''The Wild Party'' produced by Manhattan Theater Club that opens off Broadway on Feb. 24 or ''The Wild Party'' presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival/Joseph Papp Public Theater and several commercial producers that opens on Broadway on April 6? This is exactly the confusion that producers of both ''Wild Party'' productions are worried about creating in the months ahead. Both sets of producers find themselves part of what the League of American Theaters and Producers says appears to be a first for New York theater: two new musicals inspired by the same source material coming to the stage in the same season.

headline.main: Two Musicals, One Source: Is It a Duel?; Shrugging, Producers Say The Shows Must Go On

docs.lead_paragraph: A man convicted in the death of his newborn son at a Delaware motel in November 1996 was released from prison today after serving 18 months of a two-year sentence. The man, Brian C. Peterson, 21, expressed both remorse and gratitude after returning in midmorning to his mother's comfortable brick home here. He visited about an hour with family members, played with his pet cat, Princess, fed his tropical fish and then emerged to read a four-sentence statement. He seemed pale, drawn and subdued.

headline.main: Out of Prison, Student Who Disposed of Baby's Body Voices Remorse

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they did not even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper. But they made a difference in the way they lived. And they made a difference in Westchester, where they lived. Some were young, just in their 40's. Others had 90 or more years to make their mark. Some of their accomplishments were very public. Others were very private. Many were teachers at heart, even if they never set foot in a classroom or made a formal lesson plan.

headline.main: Lives Lived Well And the Lessons That They Teach

docs.lead_paragraph: Asahi Shimbun, which broke the news of Princess Masako's pregnancy, apologized today for pressuring her. She miscarried, it was announced Thursday. The newspaper said 390 people had complained about the article. ''We realized that a number of people think it is important to protect the mother's privacy,'' it said. ''For us, this was an important lesson.''
docs.abstract: Asahi Shimbun apologizes for breaking news of Princess Masako's pregnancy, which may have put pressure on her; she miscarried (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Through it all -- the Olympic gold medal for the long jump, the world record that stood for 23 years, the private audiences with heads of state -- Bob Beamon always felt like the untouched, unloved, unwanted child he was raised to believe he was. Neither the outpouring of affection from an adoring public nor the love he finally found after four failed marriages could make up for the neglect and physical abuse he suffered as a child growing up in South Jamaica, Queens. What Beamon remembers most about his childhood were the stories his father, James, and his paternal grandmother, Bessie, who raised him, told him about his mother, Naomi Brown Beamon. His mother died at age 25 when Beamon was 8 months old.
docs.abstract: Article on former long jumper Bob Beamon discusses his unhappy childhood growing up in South Jamaica, Queens; notes that his record long jump of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches at 1968 Olympics in Mexico City stood for 23 years; photos (M)
